Summary I am passionate about Wi-Fi research and creative thinking is my way of setting my standard each and every day of my research accomplishments; here are some of my accomplishments: 
 
Awards:  
 
1) Recipient of achievement award consecutively in 2014, 2013, and 2012, Nokia Research Center, Berkeley for outstanding research and innovation 
2) Recognition for perseverance and best performance of Nokia Research Center, Berkeley for the year 2013 
3) Recipient of the Best Publication Award in NRC for the year 2012 
4) Recipient of the Best Paper Award at PIMRC 2012 for the paper titled "Simultaneous 
Polling Mechanism for Low Power Sensor Networks Using ZC Sequences" with T. Kim, S. Choudhury, Z-Y. Jin, and K. Doppler  
5) Recipient of the IEEE PACRIM GOLD Award for best Communications Paper in 2011 for the paper titled "The Impact of Group Cooperation over Competitive Secondary Subnetworks" with S. Chen, A. M. Wyglinski, and S. K. Jayaweera. 
6) Elevated to IEEE Senior Member 
 
Activities: 
 
1) Member of the Executive Review Committee for preparation of IEEE 802.11ah Draft 1.0  
2) General Chair and Organizer of Wideband Mobile Cognitive Radio (WMCR 2013) in conjunction with IEEE VTC Fall 2013; it was a great success, re-defining the term "wideband" in the context of cognitive radio; 
3) Co-Chair of Cognitive Radio Sumposium for IEEE VTC Fall 2015 
4) Guest Editor for the Special Issue on Modeling and Simulation of Smart and Green Com-

puting Systems, IEEE Computer Magazine, September 2012 Experience Wireless Systems Engineer Intel Corporation October 2014  – Present (11 months) Santa Clara, California Actively contributing to IEEE standardization on next generation Wi-Fi networks; Affiliate Assistant Professor University of Washington June 2014  – Present (1 year 3 months) Seattle, WA I will be actively involved in instruction, curriculum development, undergraduate and graduate student mentoring and supervision, recruiting, and collaborative and translational research with electrical engineering faculty;  
 
I am supervising two of the doctoral theses in the Electrical Engineering Department that are well aligned with my current research focus and interest. Principal Researcher Nokia Research Center January 2014  –  October 2014  (10 months) Berkeley I have been participating in IEEE 802.11 standards meeting for the last three years. In this new role, I am leading research activities and contributions towards the creation of the IEEE 802.11ah Draft 2.0 and beyond. I am also involved in the concept creation and system architecture for the newly formed study group on High Efficiency Wireless LAN.  
 
My passion for cutting-edge research transformed into a successful collaboration with leading governmental agencies for the DARPA-funded research on Shared Spectrum Access of Radar Bands by Communications (SSPARC). I am leading the research and implementation dimensions of this project that is inherently entangled with the wave of discussions on FCC's interest in unleashing the 3.5 GHz band for commercial access. I had recently delivered a group tutorial on "Spectrum Occupancy Sensing" at the IEEE Plenary meeting on 13th July, 2014 in San Diego. The tutorial is available at  
 
https://mentor.ieee.org/802.22/dcn/14/22-14-0089-00-0000-spectrum-occupancy-sensing-tutorial-presentation.pdf 
 
I have been also entrusted with the role of managing research collaborations with the various universities in the US and Canada. I am elected as an IEEE Senior Member since February 2014. I am the Editor for IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications since April 2014. I am voluntarily serving as the Vice Chair of the IEEE Technical Committee on Simulations (TCSIM) also managing the Cognitive Radio Research group in Linkedin. Senior Researcher Nokia Research July 2011  –  December 2013  (2 years 6 months) Berkeley, CA I am the Nokia lead Delegate for IEEE Wi-Fi Standard 802.11ah (902-928 MHz). The MAC protocol adopted recently for 802.11ah networks had its inception at Nokia Research Lab, Berkeley under my leadership. Previously, I had significantly contributed to the initial draft creation phase and all throughout till the successful publication of 802.11af (TV White Spaces, 700 MHz) in February 2014. 
 
I am also leading research on DARPA's Shared Spectrum Access of Radar and Communications (SSPARC) project, infusing new research directions on shared spectrum coexistence between radars and commercial communications systems. Consequently, research efforts have been initiated with UC Berkeley and University of Washington, Seattle.  
 
As part of my intrinsic research effort at NRC, I am also leading collaborative research efforts on coexistence solutions for futuristic heterogeneous wireless networks in the TV White Spaces with distinguished faculty members of US and Canadian Universities. Last year, I was invited by the European Commission in Brussels, Belgium to review submitted proposals on emerging technologies.  
 
I am also managing the Cognitive Radio Research group in Linkedin. Post Doctoral Research Associate in the EE Department University of Washington July 2009  –  June 2011  (2 years) I was working with Prof. Sumit Roy in multitude of research topics:  
(i) Spectrum Sensing in Cognitive Radio Networks using joint optimization and convex optimization problems of sensing parameters; 
 
(ii) Performance of Heterogeneous Cognitive Networks and QoS support to secondary users and extension to Gigabit Cognitive Home Networks; 
 
(iii) Information Theoretic limits in distributed joint source channel coding techniques with Gaussian sources: this research is more directed towards Air-borne Networks; 
 
(iv) Spectrum Sharing algorithms using Game theoretic concepts and Stackelberg games;  
 
(v) Last but not the least, security in Cognitive Radio Networks. Research Assistant University of Cincinnati September 2004  –  May 2009  (4 years 9 months) I have pursued doctoral degree from the Computer Science Department. My advisor was Prof. Dharma P. Agrawal. During my graduation, my research focus was on a very exciting communication technology, Cognitive Radio Networks.  
 
I have also worked with Prof. M. B. Rao, College of Medicine, University of Cincinnati on the same research area and enjoyed theoretical research with him.  
 
The areas of Cognitive Radio Networks that I have worked in are: Spectrum Sensing, Spectrum Sharing, and a newly coined termed by us "Spectrum Selection."
